explanation:
mhd_tool_get_system_cpu_count — direct callee of detect_cpu_core_count; its implementation must be examined because any for-loops inside it (or side effects it performs) would contribute to the overall behaviour relevant to MISRA’s for-loop rule when those functions are called from inside a for statement in this function. Even though detect_cpu_core_count has no for loop now, verifying callees assures no hidden loop-related violations when code is moved/modified.

mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count — direct callee; same reason as above (possible for-loops or modifications to objects that could interact with loop control if a for loop were added or the function is inlined).

mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_special_api_, mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_sysctl_, mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_sysconf_, mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_sysctl_fallback_, mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_sysconf_fallback_ — transitive callees of mhd_tool_get_system_cpu_count (appear in the static call graph). They must be checked for any for-loop constructs or side effects that could violate the MISRA rule when those routines are invoked from within a for loop (directly or via inlining) or that modify objects potentially used as loop counters/flags.

mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_sched_getaffinity_, mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_cpuset_getaffinity_, mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_sched_getaffinity_np_, mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_w32_ — transitive callees of mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count. Same rationale: examine for any for-loops or side effects that would affect compliance if called inside a for loop or if their behaviour is considered part of a for-loop body.

MHD_REAL_CPU_COUNT — macro used as a fallback constant in detect_cpu_core_count. The macro expansion should be inspected to ensure it does not expand to an expression containing side effects or constructs that could count as illegal modifications to loop counters/flags (e.g., strange complex expressions or inline code that could introduce loops).

fprintf, printf — library calls used in the function. While their typical implementations are not relevant, check whether they are macros or inline wrappers in this build (they can be platform-specific) and thus could contain side effects or loop constructs. If they are ordinary external functions, they do not affect the for-loop well-formedness of detect_cpu_core_count, but their declarations/definitions should be confirmed.

Note: detect_cpu_core_count itself contains no for statements; the above symbols are listed so an analyst can confirm that none of the called/transitively-called functions or macros introduce for-loops or side effects that would affect MISRA C’s for-loop well-formedness if detect_cpu_core_count were modified or if those callees were invoked from inside a for loop in this codebase.
